name: Remote Systems and the Cyber Domain in Conflict
base_name: Remote Systems and the Cyber Domain in Conflict
long_desc: This course analyzes the impact of remote systems and the cyber domain on national security. We will study the development of these technologies, how and why they have been used by state and nonstate actors in conflict, their impact on the battlefield, and potential future developments. Some of the questions we will explore in this class include Are drones revolutionizing warfare between states  Does the use of drones by state actors increase or decrease terrorism, and how are terrorist groups utilizing drones to achieve their goals How does support for retaliation and escalation in response to cyber attacks differ from more traditional, kinetic attacks How have remote systems and cyber capabilities been utilized in the RussiaUkraine War

custom_fields.goals: Substantively, students will come out of this class with an understanding of the key policy and academic debates related to remote systems and the cyber domain in international conflict. This course will also help students develop their more general skillsets. For example, their writing, research, speaking, and analytical skills. This will help students succeed no matter what profession they ultimately decide to pursue.
custom_fields.key_topics: Cybersecurity, National Security, information-age conflict, internet technology, drones, missiles
custom_fields.assessment_structure: The key things students will be graded on include in-class participation, at least four mini in-class exams, a longer-form writing assignment, and at least one in-class presentation.
custom_fields.relevance: From the ubiquitous use of drones by the United States to combat terrorism and in the Russia-Ukraine War to the emergence of cyber as a new domain in warfare akin to the air, land, or sea domain, the topics we will discuss in this class are of immense relevance to international politics in the current age. Students that take this course will be better able to assess the advantages, limitations, and risks that various technologies pose to international security, as well as understand key foreign policy debates happening in Washington and around the world.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Most (and probably all) readings for class will be made available for free to students online.
